messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Contraception means ways to stop a woman from getting pregnant.
In the last 200 years, science and medicine got better.
Fewer children died young.
So the number of people grew fast.
Families were big.
Many children lived to be adults.
Then they had children too.
In the 1960s, contraception became easier to get.
After that, women had fewer babies.
The typical number went from six to about two in the world.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7077 is below the required 0.75.
- The isolated definition of contraception at the start shifts focus away from the continuous causal narrative of the original text.
- The rewritten version breaks the cause-and-effect link between technology and health improvements and rapid population growth into disjointed sentences, diluting coherence.
- The addition of standalone explanatory sentences weakens the emphasis on the original message about population growth driven by improved child survival rates.
Suggestion: Remove or reposition the standalone definition of contraception. Merge the sentences on technology, health improvements, and population growth into a single causal statement. Preserve connectors like “fuelling” or “because” to maintain the flow and strength of the original narrative.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: Because health and technology improved, fewer children died and populations grew fast.
Families were big.
Many children lived to be adults.
Then they had children too.
In the 1960s, contraception was easier to get.
Contraception is ways to stop a woman having a baby.
After that, women had fewer babies on average.
It went from six babies per woman to two.
Feedback received: Grade 2/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6648 is below the required 0.75. The simplified version removes the phrase "in the last two centuries" and reduces "fuelling rapid population growth" to "populations grew fast," losing the causal link and historical timeframe. Suggestion: Reintroduce "in the last two centuries" and "fuelling rapid population growth" and preserve the detail that large families produced even more children who survived into adulthood.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two centuries, health and technology improved.
Fewer children died young.
This made the population grow very fast.
Families were big.
Big families had many children.
Many children lived to be adults.
Then they had children too.
In the 1960s, contraception became easier to get.
Contraception means ways to stop a woman having a baby.
After that, women had fewer babies on average.
The global average fell from six babies per woman to two.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7304 is below the required 0.75, indicating that the core cause-and-effect nuance was lost.
Detected Deviations:
- MeaningBERT score 0.7304 is too low.
- The original emphasis on "fuelling rapid population growth" was removed, weakening the causal link.
Suggestions:
- Reintroduce the phrase "fuelling rapid population growth" to restore the core meaning.
- Combine simple sentences to clearly express the cause-and-effect relationship in one statement.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two centuries, health and technology improved. Fewer children died young, fuelling rapid population growth. Families were big. Big families had many children. Many children lived to be adults. Then they had children too. In the 1960s, more people could get contraception. Contraception is ways to stop a woman having a baby. After that, women had fewer babies on average. The world average fell from six to two babies per woman.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: CEFR Vocabulary Non-compliance. The text includes words above A2 level: "rapid" and "growth" are B1 vocabulary, and "fuelling" is not on the A2 list. Suggestion: Replace "fuelling rapid population growth" with A2-level wording such as "causing a fast population increase" or "leading to more people." Ensure all verbs and nouns are in the A1/A2 lists.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two centuries, health and technology improved. Fewer children died young. This made the population go up fast. Families were big. Big families had many children. Many children lived to be adults. Then they had children too. In the 1960s, more people could get contraception. Contraception means ways to stop a woman from having a baby. After that, women had fewer babies on average. The world average went from six to two babies per woman.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7319 is below the required 0.75, indicating a loss of key conceptual nuance.
1. The phrase 'population go up fast' loses the emphasis of 'rapid population growth'.
2. The omission of 'as low as' before 'two babies per woman' removes the sense of the extreme decline.
3. The simplification to 'more people could get contraception' reduces the scope of 'wider availability'.
Suggestion: Use 'rapid population growth' instead of 'population go up fast'.
Suggestion: Include 'as low as two babies per woman' to preserve nuance.
Suggestion: Restore 'wider availability of contraception' to match original emphasis.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two centuries, health and technology improved. Fewer children died young. This caused rapid population growth. Families were big. Big families had many children. Many children lived to be adults. Then they had children too. In the 1960s, there was wider availability of contraception. Contraception is ways to stop a woman from having a baby. After that, women had fewer babies on average. The world average went from six babies per woman. It fell to as low as two babies per woman.
Feedback received: Grade 5/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Deep Qualitative Audit. Vocabulary misuse.
Detected deviations:
- The word rapid is B1-level and not allowed at A2.
- The word growth is B1-level and not allowed at A2.
- The word availability is C1-level and not allowed at A2.
- The word ways is not on the A2 list.
- The word adults is not on the A2 list.
Corrective actions:
Replace rapid with fast. Replace growth with increase. Replace availability with more access. Remove ways by saying "methods to stop a woman from having a baby" or similar simpler phrase. Replace adults with grown-up people.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two centuries, health and technology improved. Fewer children died young. This caused fast population increase. Families were big. Big families had many children. Many children lived to be grown-up people. Then they had children too. In the 1960s, there was more access to contraception. Contraception means methods to stop a woman from having a baby. After that, women had fewer babies on average. The world average went from six babies per woman. It fell to as low as two babies per woman.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text:
FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.7155 is too low.
- The writer’s output overemphasises a definition of contraception and dilutes the original focus on population growth trends.
- The causal link “fuelling rapid population growth” is weakened to “This caused fast population increase,” losing the continuous reinforcement nuance.
- The streamlined sentences split key ideas and reduce the emphasis on the global average decline from six to two babies per woman as a direct result of contraception availability.
Suggestion: Reinstate the phrase “fuelling rapid population growth.” Merge sentences to restore clear cause-and-effect. Remove or relocate the contraception definition and keep the focus on declining birth rates.

messages.content: Text created/updated with CEFR level A2

Text saved: In the last two centuries, health and technology improved. Fewer children died young. This fuelled rapid population growth. Families were large. Large families had even more children. Many children lived to be adults. Then they had their own children. In the 1960s, contraception became more widely available. Contraception is ways to stop pregnancy. After that, the world average fell. It went from six babies per woman to as low as two.
Feedback received: Grade 3/10 - FAIL

metadata.feedback_text: FAIL: Vocabulary Audit Failure. The text uses words above the A2 level. The sentence “This fuelled rapid population growth.” contains the B1 words rapid and growth. The phrase “more widely available” includes the B2 word widely. The definition “ways to stop pregnancy” uses the C1 word pregnancy. A2 level forbids B1/B2/C1 vocabulary. Suggestion: replace rapid with fast, growth with increase, widely with more, and pregnancy with having a baby or becoming a parent.

Many children lived to be adults. Then they had their own children. In the 1960s, contraception became more available. Contraception means ways to stop having a baby. After that, the world average fell. It went from six babies per woman to as low as two.

Suggestion: Replace “means” with a simpler verb or phrase, for example, rephrase as “Contraception is a way to stop having a baby.” Ensure all words are on the approved A2 list.
